title: Instagram influencer accused of hijacking wedding by wearing white
text:
Noemi, left, was shamed for turning up to her friend’s wedding wearing a white dress – but she says the dress was clearly beige – and was marked ‘brown’ on the website where she bought it (Picture: Reddit)

Despite it being the ultimate fashion faux pas, it seems some people can’t resist wearing white to a wedding.

Even if the dress isn’t white, if it’s ‘in the white spectrum’, it’s just as big a crime as choosing white – as one woman discovered when she wore a light-coloured dress and white blazer to her friend’s big day – and was subsequently roasted online for her outfit.

A photo of the guest and the bride posing together in what appeared to be white dresses was shared on Reddit’s wedding shaming thread, where the move was branded ‘tacky’.

‘That’s tacky as f*** to do that,’ wrote one person. ‘Not to mention bringing your own bouquet!’ chimed in another. ‘I’m swinging if this happens at my wedding,’ and ‘Can we not curse her or something?’ were two more comments.

The guest in question has been identified by Metro.co.uk as Noemi, a 27-year-old Hungarian Instagram influencer who attended her friend’s wedding.

Metro.co.uk contacted Noemi to get the full story. She tells us that the £24 (8,995 Hungarian forints) Bershka dress she purchased for her friend’s wedding is officially ‘brown’ and that she cleared her outfit choice with the bride ahead of the event.

She said: ‘This whole story is ridiculous… really.

‘My dress is BEIGE… not white. My dress is actually called “BROWN” on the website (it has a white version but I bought the “BROWN”) “Barna” means brown…’

The £24 dress as it is pictured and described on the Bershka website – sold as the colour ‘brown’. There is a white version on sale as well

Being officially brown is not enough defence for the wedding shamers though. They say that her dress appears off-white, which makes it inappropriate to wear it as it is ‘in the spectrum of white’.

One use wrote: ‘Technically she isn’t wearing white (but still in the white area category and tacky AF).

‘Her coat/blazer though is white. The dress looks good and definitely not wedding appropriate.’

Another said: ‘There are some shades of light pink/light blue/light yellow that I wouldn’t even wear to a wedding because they could look close to white in pics, let alone off white.

Another wrote: ‘It’s linen. And WAY too close to white to wear to a wedding without looking like an insecure narcissist screaming for attention.’

Others were more upset at the fact Noemi was holding the bride’s bouquet in the photo.

One person said: ‘I wonder why she’s holding the bouquet like that. Is she showing off her lines or something? Making sure we see the whole outfit?’

Not everyone was quite so brutal – one person didn’t see an issue with Noemi’s dress.

‘Look, and I’ll probably get down voted for this […], but I don’t see the big deal here,’ the person wrote.

‘Yes, it’s whiteish but it’s midi length and a textured casual fabric (linen) that I doubt could ever be confused with a wedding gown.

‘While I personally wouldn’t wear this to a wedding, I wouldn’t be annoyed if someone wore it to mine. I don’t think it takes away from the bride one bit, I mean come on, she’s the bride, I doubt anyone would confuse her for someone else.’

On the bouquet, Noemi says: ‘There is a tradition in Hungary that the bride throws her bouquet and who grabs it, will be the next one who gets married… I am not engaged (I’ve been waiting for it for years now…) and I grabbed the bouquet…

‘Btw, the bride is one of my best friends on the photo and I actually showed her the dress before the wedding and she really really liked [it]…

‘So I am not a wedding crasher, I DID NOT STEAL the wedding bouquet… And my shoes are actually light pink.’
